citeinfo.title: Spring Index Return Interval, First Bloom
USA National Phenology Network, Gridded Data Product Suite

descript.abstract: The Spring Index Return Interval for first bloom represents the frequency with which spring is as late or early as it is in the current year. It serves to contextualize the current year’s spring onset anomaly. For example, if the Daily Anomaly product shows first bloom occurring 20 days earlier than average, for a given location, the Return Interval product shows how often that location has experienced bloom at least 20 days early. To create this product, the current year Spring Index Anomaly value is compared to the anomaly value for the preceding decades (2019 and 2020 are compared preceding 38 and 39 years respectively; 2021 and subsequent years are compared to the preceding 40 years). The frequency with which a spring was at least this early (or late) is calculated by taking the number of years in the record divided by the count of years that were earlier (or later) than the current year. Values of 0 represent average or “on time” springs. Negative values represent the frequency of early springs; positive values represent the frequency of late springs. Values of 41 represent the earliest (-41) or latest (41) spring on record.
descript.purpose: The Spring Index Return Interval contextualizes the current year's spring relative to the historical record, answering a key question about how typical an early or late spring is.

citeinfo.title: Spring Indices, Daily Anomaly - Daily Spring Index Bloom Anomaly

srcinfo.srccontr: Provides the current year values for spring arrival.

procstep.procdesc: Rescale USA-NPN Spring Indices, Historical Annual Anomaly (1981-Previous Year) - First Bloom Anomaly (4KM) to match USA-NPN Spring Indices, Daily Anomaly - Daily Spring Index Bloom Anomaly (current year, 2.5KM)
Where the current year anomaly is 0, maintain that 0 through to the output raster. These pixels experienced an “on time” spring.

Compare the current year anomaly value to each of the historical annual anomaly layers, determining for each non-zero pixel, a count of the years that the current year anomaly value was equal to or greater than the historical value.
Divide the count obtained in the previous step by the number of years in the historical record. This is the frequency of a spring as early or late as the current year.

Some pixels will be “NA” or “inf” as a result of dividing the number of years in the record by a count of 0. These represent unprecedented early or late springs. The are set to -41 for the earliest spring on record and 41 for the latest spring on record.
